awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Quantum Resistant Cloud-Based Vault Service for Cryptocurrency Key Backup and Recovery
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Phase I Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to significantly reduce the economic and national security threats posed by the persistent theft of billions in digital assets by cyber criminals and adversarial nation states. This project solves the problem of private key mismanagement as one of the most common attacks suffered by investors, digital asset custodians, businesses and law enforcement agencies. This project’s innovation will address the technical challenge of secure and privacy-preserving cryptographic key management. Current key backup and recovery (KBR) products are cost-prohibitive, expose keys to third parties, and have recovery processes which can take up to 48 hours. This project will develop a cloud-based vault that utilizes quantum-resistant cryptography that securely stores cryptocurrency keys while guaranteeing privacy and a faster recovery process. Fundamental scientific advancements from this project will demonstrate the potential of quantum-resistant KBR, and will lead to advancements in public key infrastructure. Commercialization efforts will lead to a new product that provides crucial support to target markets, including institutional investors and government investigators. This, in turn, will lead to improved economic competitiveness, national defense, and enhanced STEM (Science Technology Engineering and Math) workforce development by advancing the field of cryptography.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to address digital asset security risks stemming from improper key management by demonstrating the technical feasibility of a cloud-based vault service (CBVS) utilizing multiple concurrent cryptographic protocols, including quantum-resistant threshold fully homomorphic encryption (FHE). The system will enable cryptocurrency keys to be securely stored, sharded, distributed among multiple data centers or commercial cloud providers and instantly reconstituted at will. This research aims to optimally integrate and implement FHE into the design of the CBVS to ensure efficient and secure processing, storage and recovery of secret keys while maintaining privacy and preventing third party key exposure. This includes defining the data model, encryption schemes, access controls and authentication mechanisms to protect private keys from unauthorized access or exposure while striking a balance between security and usability. A comprehensive, scalable key management system will be developed within the vault to enable users to securely generate, store and retrieve private keys as needed while enforcing strict access control and maintaining an audit trail for key operations. By addressing key technical challenges and reducing technical risk, this research will pave the way for a commercially viable and impactful product that can revolutionize the cryptocurrency security landscape.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Crypto Asset Technology (CAT) Labs has developed the world's first quantum-resistant cloud-based vault service (CBVS) for cryptocurrency key backup and recovery (KBR). Cryptocurrency private keys are critical for accessing and transferring digital assets. Secure key storage and recovery are essential, since any exposure of private keys enables attackers to steal funds by moving them to their own accounts. Our solution addresses key challenges through a combination of threshold-based encryption, multiple concurrent encryptions, and role-based access control, ensuring that no single entity can unilaterally recover cryptographic keys. We validated the system’s security through prototype development, performance benchmarking, and integration with standard cloud key management systems, demonstrating its interoperability with enterprise IT environments. Rigorous testing confirmed that our system mitigates unauthorized access risks, protects against emerging quantum threats, and supports secure key recovery even in high-turnover institutional settings.

Current KBR systems rely on splitting keys between distant secure physical facilities, often requiring more than 48 hours for key recovery. Our system eliminates the need for costly and inefficient physical bunkers by using layered multiple concurrent quantum-resistant encryption schemes, including Threshold Fully Homomorphic Encryption (TFHE), to backup and recover private keys. The threshold property of TFHE ensures that decryption requires collaboration among multiple parties, preventing any single entity from decrypting the key alone. By combining layered TFHE with other cryptographic primitives, we have developed a role-based quantum-resistant key vault that can operate in untrusted environments, including cloud platforms, making our secure KBR solution faster, more affordable, and more flexible than existing solutions, while opening the door for other secrets management applications beyond cryptocurrency keys. 

During this research, CAT Labs has also uncovered the unique pain points of government law enforcement, intelligence, and defense agencies handling petabytes of sensitive case data often containing cryptocurrency private keys and other sensitive data. As a result, CAT Labs laid the foundation to ensure the CBVS can help address critical challenges in cryptographic key management, auditability, user management, and secure digital data handling during government investigations as they triage digital data containing sensitive artifacts and digital assets. To this end, the CBVS was built for interoperability with government user management and access control systems, digital asset recovery and custody platforms, investigative tools, data analytics, cybersecurity solutions, forensic tools, and IT systems. This lays the groundwork for the integration of quantum-resistant sensitive data and secrets management systems into various investigative, intelligence, data analytics and forensic workflows. During this research, CAT Labs also developed elements of a digital asset recovery software platform that allows government investigators to scan digital evidence for cryptocurrency private keys. The CBVS was built with the ability to integrate with this digital asset recovery software to allow for the secure management of private keys detected during digital data triage. 

Our KBR system fills critical gaps in digital asset security, disaster recovery, and law enforcement investigations. With the digital asset custody market projected to reach $4.6 trillion by 2033, inadequate key management leaves assets vulnerable to cyber threats, as evidenced by over $6 billion in digital assets already stolen by adversarial nation-states. Law enforcement faces challenges managing over $20 billion in seized digital assets due to operational risks as they triage data containing cryptocurrency private keys. This research will also offer government agencies essential tools to comply with the March 6, 2025 Executive Order ESTABLISHMENT OF THE STRATEGIC BITCOIN RESERVE AND UNITED STATES DIGITAL ASSET STOCKPILE, which directs federal agencies to account for all digital asset holdings in their possession, and to centralize and secure those assets within the U.S. Digital Asset Stockpile, ensuring full transparency and oversight of seized cryptocurrency. The technology developed in this project empowers government agencies to maximize digital asset seizures and ensure the secure management of cryptocurrency private keys. The continued development, commercialization and workflow integration of this technology will help the United States stand out as a leading technology producer in the digital financial technology sector, while deterring national security threats posed by the nefarious misuse of digital assets.
